subcategories.name: General Administration & Office Procedures
subcategories.description: Administrative procedures, records, and office governance.

questions.question: According to PSR 010101, the Public Service Rules are made under the authority of:
options: The Constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria
The Head of the Civil Service alone
questions.explanation: PSR 010101 provides that the Public Service Rules derive their authority from the Constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.

questions.question: PSR 010102 states that the Rules apply to:
options: All public officers in the Federal Civil Service
questions.explanation: PSR 010102 specifies that the Rules apply to all officers in the Federal Public Service unless otherwise provided by law.

questions.question: Under PSR 010103, interpretation of the Rules is vested in:
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: PSR 010103 provides that the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation is the authority for interpretation of the Rules.

questions.question: PSR 010104 emphasizes that the Rules must be:
options: Applied uniformly and in good faith
questions.explanation: PSR 010104 states that the Rules must be applied consistently and in good faith to ensure equity and fairness in administration.

questions.question: PSR 010105 provides that matters not expressly covered by the Rules shall be referred to:
options: The Head of the Civil Service for clarification
questions.explanation: PSR 010105 mandates referral of any administrative matter not specifically covered by the Rules to the Head of the Civil Service.

questions.question: According to PSR 010106, any circular issued by the Office of the Head of the Civil Service shall:
options: Have equal authority as the Rules
questions.explanation: PSR 010106 declares that establishment circulars issued by the Office of the Head of the Civil Service have the same binding authority as the Rules.

questions.question: PSR 010107 stipulates that amendments to the Rules may only be made with the approval of:
options: The Head of Service and the President
questions.explanation: PSR 010107 provides that amendments to the Public Service Rules require the approval of the President through the Head of Service.

questions.question: Under PSR 110101, official correspondence must be conducted:
questions.explanation: PSR 110101 provides that all official correspondence must follow established administrative channels to maintain accountability.

questions.question: PSR 110102 provides that internal communications between departments should be made through:
questions.explanation: PSR 110102 stipulates that communications within Ministries or Departments must be conducted via official memos or notes.

questions.question: According to PSR 110103, classified correspondence must be handled:
questions.explanation: PSR 110103 provides that confidential and secret correspondence must be handled under secure and controlled conditions.

questions.question: PSR 110104 specifies that all official files should contain:
options: Chronological records of action and references
questions.explanation: PSR 110104 directs that every file must show a chronological record of correspondence and actions taken for transparency.

questions.question: Under PSR 110105, outgoing mail should be dispatched:
questions.explanation: PSR 110105 states that outgoing official correspondence should be dispatched within 24 hours of signature.

questions.question: According to PSR 110106, each Ministry must maintain:
options: A record registry for mail and files
questions.explanation: PSR 110106 provides that Ministries must maintain a registry for efficient control and documentation of incoming and outgoing correspondence.

questions.question: PSR 110107 provides that official documents classified as secret must be kept in:
options: A safe or secure cabinet under lock
questions.explanation: PSR 110107 stipulates that classified documents must be securely stored in safes or lockable cabinets with restricted access.

questions.question: PSR 110108 emphasizes that file references must include:
questions.explanation: PSR 110108 requires that file references contain both file number and subject heading for clarity and easy retrieval.

questions.question: Under PSR 110109, routine correspondence between Ministries should be:
questions.explanation: PSR 110109 directs that all inter-ministerial correspondence must pass through the Permanent Secretary for coordination.

questions.question: PSR 110110 provides that Ministers or Commissioners may issue directives:
options: Through official channels of the Permanent Secretary
questions.explanation: PSR 110110 provides that ministerial directives must be transmitted through the Permanent Secretary to maintain order and accountability.

questions.question: According to PSR 110111, destruction of official records requires:
questions.explanation: PSR 110111 mandates that no official record shall be destroyed without written approval of the authorized officer.

questions.question: PSR 110112 states that official correspondence to external bodies must be signed by:
options: The authorized signatory or Permanent Secretary
questions.explanation: PSR 110112 specifies that external correspondence must be signed only by the Permanent Secretary or authorized signatory.

questions.question: PSR 110113 directs that copies of official correspondence should be:
options: Filed properly in the Ministryâ€™s registry
questions.explanation: PSR 110113 provides that copies of all official letters should be retained in the Ministryâ€™s registry for reference and recordkeeping.

questions.question: According to PSR 110114, the receipt of official mail should be acknowledged:
questions.explanation: PSR 110114 provides that all official correspondence received must be acknowledged within 24 hours to ensure accountability.

questions.question: PSR 110115 states that office minutes must be written:
options: Clearly, concisely, and in impersonal language
questions.explanation: PSR 110115 requires that official minutes be brief, impersonal, and written in clear language to convey decisions effectively.

questions.question: PSR 110116 emphasizes that official telephone conversations of importance must be:
questions.explanation: PSR 110116 provides that official conversations or decisions made by phone must be recorded or noted in writing for record purposes.

questions.question: Under PSR 110117, misplacement of official files is regarded as:
questions.explanation: PSR 110117 classifies misplacement or loss of official files as negligence and misconduct subject to disciplinary action.

questions.question: According to PSR 110118, government vehicles and equipment shall be used:
options: For personal errands when official work is done
questions.explanation: PSR 110118 prohibits personal use of government vehicles and equipment; they must be used strictly for official duties.

questions.question: Under PSR 110119, the head of a department is responsible for ensuring that:
options: Government property and records are properly maintained
questions.explanation: PSR 110119 assigns responsibility to departmental heads for proper maintenance of government property and official records.

questions.question: PSR 110120 provides that government offices must remain open to the public between:
questions.explanation: PSR 110120 prescribes official working hours from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Mondays to Fridays, except on public holidays.

questions.question: According to PSR 110121, late arrival to duty without permission is considered:
questions.explanation: PSR 110121 classifies lateness and unauthorized absence as negligence of duty and a disciplinary offence.

questions.question: PSR 110122 requires that staff attendance be recorded in:
questions.explanation: PSR 110122 directs that all Ministries maintain an attendance register for daily record of officersâ€™ presence at work.

questions.question: Under PSR 110123, officers are required to report for duty:
questions.explanation: PSR 110123 requires punctual attendance and adherence to official hours of duty by all officers.

questions.question: PSR 110124 provides that officers who need to leave duty before closing time must:
options: Sign the movement register with permission
Send a text message to supervisor
questions.explanation: PSR 110124 requires officers to obtain permission and sign the movement register before leaving duty before closing hours.

questions.question: According to PSR 110125, when an officer is absent without permission for ten consecutive days, it shall be treated as:
questions.explanation: PSR 110125 deems absence without permission for ten working days as resignation from service with forfeiture of benefits.

questions.question: PSR 110126 provides that all Ministries must ensure adequate:
questions.explanation: PSR 110126 emphasizes proper filing systems and control of records to ensure administrative efficiency.

questions.question: Under PSR 110127, officers responsible for mail handling must:
options: Keep proper registers of incoming and outgoing mails
questions.explanation: PSR 110127 mandates proper recordkeeping of all incoming and outgoing correspondence through designated mail registers.

questions.question: PSR 110128 states that officers must use official email and correspondence channels to:
questions.explanation: PSR 110128 encourages use of official email systems to ensure record traceability and prevent data breaches.

questions.question: According to PSR 110129, officers responsible for registry work must be trained in:
questions.explanation: PSR 110129 directs that registry officers should be trained in modern records and information management for efficiency.

questions.question: PSR 110130 provides that all correspondences should be signed and dated to:
questions.explanation: PSR 110130 emphasizes signing and dating of documents to ensure authenticity and accountability.

questions.question: Under PSR 110131, officers must not remove official documents from office without:
questions.explanation: PSR 110131 prohibits unauthorized removal of government documents except with written authorization from a superior officer.

questions.question: PSR 110132 provides that minutes of official meetings must be:
options: Filed, numbered, and preserved for reference
questions.explanation: PSR 110132 requires that all minutes of official meetings be properly filed and preserved for audit and reference.

questions.question: PSR 110133 provides that reports or returns requested by superior authorities must be:
questions.explanation: PSR 110133 mandates that reports requested by higher authorities be submitted accurately and without delay.

questions.question: Under PSR 110134, waste of government stationery and materials is classified as:
questions.explanation: PSR 110134 considers waste or careless use of government stationery as negligence requiring disciplinary action.

questions.question: PSR 110135 requires that all Ministries keep:
questions.explanation: PSR 110135 requires each Ministry to maintain a Visitorsâ€™ Book to record all official visits and inquiries.

questions.question: According to PSR 110136, officers responsible for stores and inventory must:
options: Keep stock ledgers and update balances regularly
questions.explanation: PSR 110136 requires store officers to maintain up-to-date stock ledgers for accountability and audit purposes.

questions.question: PSR 110137 provides that confidential records should be accessed only by:
questions.explanation: PSR 110137 stipulates that access to confidential records is restricted to duly authorized officers only.

questions.question: Under PSR 110138, misuse of official information is punishable as:
questions.explanation: PSR 110138 classifies misuse or unauthorized disclosure of official information as serious misconduct.

questions.question: PSR 110139 directs that records of staff discipline and performance be:
questions.explanation: PSR 110139 mandates proper filing of disciplinary and performance records in officersâ€™ personal files for reference.

questions.question: According to PSR 110140, annual reports from Ministries should reach the Head of Service by:
options: End of January following the year under review
questions.explanation: PSR 110140 provides that annual reports must be submitted to the Head of Service by the end of January following the review year.

questions.question: PSR 110141 emphasizes that administrative instructions shall be:
questions.explanation: PSR 110141 directs that all administrative instructions must be put in writing to maintain accountability and documentation.

questions.question: PSR 110142 provides that obsolete files may be destroyed after:
options: Approval of the authorized officer and proper record
questions.explanation: PSR 110142 mandates that obsolete files may only be destroyed after approval of an authorized officer and documentation.

questions.question: The general purpose of Chapter 11 of the PSR is to:
options: Ensure effective administrative coordination and record integrity
questions.explanation: Chapter 11 of the PSR ensures proper administrative coordination, accountability, and efficient record management across the Civil Service.

questions.question: According to PSR 180101, the Public Service Rules 2021 came into effect on:
questions.explanation: PSR 180101 provides that the Public Service Rules 2021 took effect from 27th July 2021 as approved by the President.

questions.question: PSR 180102 provides that interpretation of any rule shall be the responsibility of:
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: PSR 180102 vests interpretation authority in the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation.

questions.question: According to PSR 180103, in the event of conflict between PSR and an Establishment Circular, precedence shall be given to:
questions.explanation: PSR 180103 provides that where a conflict arises, the provisions of the Public Service Rules prevail over any circular or instruction.

questions.question: Under PSR 180104, 'Commission' refers to:
questions.explanation: PSR 180104 defines 'Commission' as the Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC).

questions.question: According to PSR 180105, 'Permanent Secretary' means:
options: The administrative head of a Ministry or extra-ministerial department
A staff of any grade level
questions.explanation: PSR 180105 defines 'Permanent Secretary' as the administrative head of a Ministry or extra-ministerial office.

questions.question: PSR 180106 defines 'officer' as:
options: Any person employed in a civil capacity in the Public Service of the Federation
A member of the Armed Forces
questions.explanation: PSR 180106 defines an 'officer' as a person employed in a civil capacity in the Public Service of the Federation.

questions.question: Under PSR 180107, 'Ministry' includes:
options: Any Federal Ministry or extra-ministerial office
questions.explanation: PSR 180107 clarifies that 'Ministry' includes any Federal Ministry or extra-ministerial office under the Federal Government.

questions.question: According to PSR 180108, the term 'President' refers to:
options: The President and Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of the Federal Republic of Nigeria
questions.explanation: PSR 180108 defines 'President' as the President and Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.

questions.question: PSR 180109 defines 'Commissionâ€™s power' to include:
options: Recruitment, promotion, and discipline of officers
questions.explanation: PSR 180109 provides that the Commission exercises powers of appointment, promotion, and discipline over public officers.

questions.question: Under PSR 180110, the phrase 'Head of Civil Service' refers to:
options: The administrative head of the entire Federal Civil Service
questions.explanation: PSR 180110 defines the Head of Civil Service as the administrative head of the Federal Civil Service and custodian of the Rules.

questions.question: PSR 180111 defines 'Public Service' as including:
options: All Federal Ministries, Departments, and Agencies under the executive arm
questions.explanation: PSR 180111 includes all Ministries, Departments, and Agencies under the Federal Government as part of the Public Service.

questions.question: According to PSR 180112, 'Serious misconduct' means:
options: Specific act that can lead to dismissal
questions.explanation: PSR 180112 defines 'serious misconduct' as a specific act that can lead to dismissal from service.

questions.question: PSR 180113 provides that 'misconduct' means:
questions.explanation: PSR 180113 defines 'misconduct' as failure to perform duties properly or violation of established rules and regulations.

questions.question: Under PSR 180114, 'Permanent and Pensionable appointment' means:
options: An appointment that qualifies the holder for pension benefits
questions.explanation: PSR 180114 defines a permanent and pensionable appointment as one which qualifies the holder for pension benefits after confirmation.

questions.question: PSR 180115 defines 'Temporary appointment' as:
options: An employment with no pension rights until confirmation
questions.explanation: PSR 180115 defines temporary appointment as employment without pension benefits until the officer is confirmed.

questions.question: According to PSR 180116, 'Salary' means:
options: All approved emoluments including allowances and increments
questions.explanation: PSR 180116 defines salary as all approved emoluments including basic pay, allowances, and approved increments.

questions.question: PSR 180117 states that 'Head of Department' means:
options: An officer in charge of a recognized department or division in a Ministry
questions.explanation: PSR 180117 defines 'Head of Department' as the officer responsible for a department or division recognized by the Government.

questions.question: PSR 180118 provides that 'Confirmation of appointment' means:
options: Formal acceptance of satisfactory service after probation
questions.explanation: PSR 180118 defines confirmation as formal recognition of satisfactory completion of probation.

questions.question: Under PSR 180119, the term 'Minister' refers to:
options: A member of the Federal Executive Council in charge of a Ministry
questions.explanation: PSR 180119 defines 'Minister' as a member of the Federal Executive Council responsible for a Ministry.

questions.question: According to PSR 180120, 'Extra-Ministerial Office' means:
options: A Federal Government office not forming part of a Ministry
questions.explanation: PSR 180120 defines an extra-ministerial office as a Federal Government agency not forming part of a Ministry.

questions.question: PSR 180121 clarifies that 'Commissioner' in the context of the Rules refers to:
options: Federal Commissioner in the Civil Service Commission
questions.explanation: PSR 180121 defines 'Commissioner' as a member of the Federal Civil Service Commission.

questions.question: PSR 180122 defines 'Probation' as:
options: A temporary period for assessment before confirmation
questions.explanation: PSR 180122 defines probation as a temporary period of assessment before confirmation of appointment.

questions.question: Under PSR 180123, 'Promotion' means:
options: Elevation to a higher grade level with greater responsibility
questions.explanation: PSR 180123 defines promotion as the advancement of an officer to a higher post with increased responsibility.

questions.question: PSR 180124 states that 'Transfer' refers to:
options: Movement between posts of equal grade level and status
questions.explanation: PSR 180124 defines transfer as movement of an officer from one post to another of equivalent grade and status.

questions.question: According to PSR 180125, the phrase 'Head of Government Department' refers to:
options: The senior-most officer in a department responsible for administration
Any officer at Grade Level 10 and above
questions.explanation: PSR 180125 defines 'Head of Government Department' as the senior-most officer responsible for departmental administration and efficiency.

questions.question: PSR 180126 defines 'Posting' as:
options: Assignment of an officer to a new duty station or position
questions.explanation: PSR 180126 defines 'posting' as the formal assignment of an officer to a new duty station or position within the Service.

questions.question: According to PSR 180127, the term 'Seniority' refers to:
options: Length of service in a grade relative to others
questions.explanation: PSR 180127 defines seniority as the relative length of service in a grade level compared with other officers.

questions.question: PSR 180128 provides that 'Temporary Transfer' means:
options: A transfer for a limited period subject to return
questions.explanation: PSR 180128 defines temporary transfer as a redeployment of an officer for a limited period after which the officer returns to the parent Ministry.

questions.question: Under PSR 180129, 'Acting Appointment' is defined as:
options: Temporary assignment to perform duties of a higher office
questions.explanation: PSR 180129 defines acting appointment as a temporary assignment to perform the duties of a higher office pending substantive appointment.

questions.question: PSR 180130 defines 'Leave' as:
options: Temporary absence from duty officially approved by authority
questions.explanation: PSR 180130 defines leave as an officially approved temporary absence from duty for a specified period.

questions.question: PSR 180131 provides that 'Efficiency' means:
options: Ability to complete duties with diligence and accuracy
questions.explanation: PSR 180131 defines efficiency as the ability of an officer to perform assigned duties effectively, promptly, and accurately.

questions.question: According to PSR 180132, 'Retirement' refers to:
options: Cessation of service after attaining statutory age or years of service
questions.explanation: PSR 180132 defines retirement as the cessation of service after attaining the statutory age or years of qualifying service.

questions.question: Under PSR 180133, 'Discipline' means:
options: Control exercised over conduct to maintain order and efficiency
questions.explanation: PSR 180133 defines discipline as the control and corrective measures employed to ensure good conduct and order in the Service.

questions.question: PSR 180134 states that 'Dismissal' means:
options: Removal from service as a disciplinary measure without benefits
questions.explanation: PSR 180134 defines dismissal as removal from the Service as a disciplinary measure with forfeiture of all benefits.

questions.question: PSR 180135 defines 'Termination' as:
options: Disengagement of an officer for reasons other than discipline
questions.explanation: PSR 180135 defines termination as the cessation of an officerâ€™s appointment for administrative or efficiency reasons other than discipline.

questions.question: According to PSR 180136, 'Probationer' means:
options: An officer serving a trial period before confirmation
questions.explanation: PSR 180136 defines a probationer as an officer serving a trial period before confirmation.

questions.question: PSR 180137 defines 'Temporary Staff' as:
options: Officers appointed for a limited period pending confirmation or replacement
questions.explanation: PSR 180137 defines temporary staff as officers employed for a limited duration pending confirmation or replacement.

questions.question: Under PSR 180138, 'Emoluments' mean:
options: Total monetary and non-monetary benefits payable to an officer
questions.explanation: PSR 180138 defines emoluments as all monetary and non-monetary benefits payable to an officer in respect of service rendered.

questions.question: PSR 180139 provides that 'Seniority list' shall be maintained by:
options: Each Ministry or Department under supervision of the Commission
questions.explanation: PSR 180139 directs every Ministry to maintain a seniority list supervised by the Federal Civil Service Commission.

questions.question: PSR 180140 defines 'Establishment Circular' as:
options: An official directive issued by the Office of the Head of Service
questions.explanation: PSR 180140 defines an establishment circular as an official directive from the Office of the Head of Civil Service of the Federation.

questions.question: According to PSR 190101, the repeal of the 2008 PSR means:
options: The 2008 edition ceases to have effect
questions.explanation: PSR 190101 repeals the 2008 edition, meaning only the 2021 edition governs all matters from its commencement date.

questions.question: PSR 190102 provides that disciplinary cases pending before the 2021 Rules:
options: Shall continue under the old Rules until concluded
questions.explanation: PSR 190102 provides that disciplinary cases already initiated before the 2021 PSR shall continue under the 2008 edition until determination.

questions.question: PSR 190103 provides that appointments made before 2021 shall:
options: Be reconfirmed under the new PSR
Remain valid as if made under the 2021 PSR
questions.explanation: PSR 190103 validates all appointments and actions taken under the repealed Rules as if made under the 2021 edition.

questions.question: Under PSR 190104, the interpretation of transitional provisions rests with:
options: The Head of Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: PSR 190104 places interpretation of transitional and commencement provisions under the authority of the Head of Civil Service.

questions.question: PSR 190105 directs that references to repealed provisions in other laws shall be construed as:
options: References to the corresponding provisions in PSR 2021
questions.explanation: PSR 190105 provides that any legal reference to repealed PSR sections shall now refer to equivalent provisions in PSR 2021.

questions.question: According to PSR 190106, the short title of these Rules shall be:
questions.explanation: PSR 190106 provides that the Rules shall be cited as the Public Service Rules 2021.

questions.question: PSR 190107 states that these Rules supersede:
options: All previous editions and inconsistent circulars
questions.explanation: PSR 190107 states that the 2021 Rules supersede all prior editions and circulars inconsistent with their provisions.

questions.question: PSR 190108 mandates Ministries to:
options: Print and distribute copies of PSR 2021 to all staff
questions.explanation: PSR 190108 requires every Ministry and Department to make copies of PSR 2021 available to all officers.

questions.question: According to PSR 190109, any circular inconsistent with PSR 2021 shall:
options: Be regarded as void to the extent of inconsistency
questions.explanation: PSR 190109 invalidates any circular that contradicts the provisions of the 2021 Public Service Rules.

questions.question: The overall purpose of Chapters 18 and 19 of PSR 2021 is to:
options: Clarify definitions, establish commencement, and ensure smooth transition
questions.explanation: Chapters 18 and 19 aim to provide clear definitions, establish commencement authority, and ensure a seamless transition from previous PSR editions.

subcategories.name: Circulars: Appointments, Tenure & Discipline
subcategories.description: Official circular updates on appointments, tenure and discipline.

questions.question: The Tenure Policy Circular limits the tenure of career Directors (GL 17) and Permanent Secretaries to a maximum of:
questions.explanation: The Tenure Policy Circular (reaffirmed in 2016 and 2017) limits the tenure of Permanent Secretaries and Directors to a maximum of eight years to ensure succession and renewal [1, 2].

questions.question: The 2017 Circular on Tenure Review emphasized the strict adherence to the 8-year limit for Directors primarily to achieve:
options: Succession planning and avoidance of career stagnation
Reduction in staff strength across MDAs
Exemption of technical staff from retirement
questions.explanation: The 2017 Circular reaffirmed strict adherence to the 8-year tenure limit for Directors to prevent stagnation and facilitate succession planning [2].

questions.question: Under the 2013 Circular, what is the minimum consecutive period an officer must serve in an acting appointment before qualifying for the payment of acting allowance?
questions.explanation: The 2013 OHCSF Circular clarified that an officer must act for a minimum of 14 days before qualifying for the payment of acting allowance [3].

questions.question: Which body retains the primary authority for discipline over officers on the established cadre (GL 07 and above), as reinforced by the 2015 Disciplinary Circulars?
options: The Office of the Head of Service (OHCSF)
questions.explanation: The 2015 Circular on disciplinary procedures reaffirmed that disciplinary powers for officers on the established cadre remain vested in the FCSC [4, 5].

questions.question: If an officer’s transfer is at their own request, extant circulars (based on PSR Rule 140137) clarify they are entitled to:
questions.explanation: An Officer whose transfer is at his own request shall be entitled to only transport allowance and not resettlement allowance [6].

questions.question: Under delegated authority, who is authorized to promote eligible candidates to delegated posts on SGL 06 or its equivalent and below?
questions.explanation: Permanent Secretaries/Heads of Extra-Ministerial Offices are authorized to promote eligible candidates to delegated posts on SGL 06 or its equivalent and below [7].

questions.question: The period of secondment to an approved body or recognized international organization shall not exceed:
questions.explanation: The period of secondment shall not exceed six years [8].

questions.question: An officer who fails the compulsory confirmation examination (COMPRO) after three consecutive attempts is required to:
options: Resign or be withdrawn from the service
Proceed on compulsory leave without pay
questions.explanation: Failure after three consecutive attempts requires the officer to resign or be withdrawn from the service [9].

questions.question: Who is responsible for notifying the Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC) of cessation of acting appointments using Form No. Gen. 15A?
questions.explanation: Ministries shall be required to notify the FCSC when officers revert from acting appointment by completion of Form No. Gen. 15A [10].

questions.question: The duration of probation for first appointments shall not exceed two years unless an extension is approved by the:
questions.explanation: The period of probation shall not exceed two years unless an extension is approved by the FCSC [11, 12].

questions.question: An officer may be interdicted or suspended if their work or conduct results in adverse comments. The objective of conveying such reports in 'sympathetic terms' is to encourage the officer to overcome their:
questions.explanation: The objective of reporting adverse comments in sympathetic terms is enabling and encouraging him to overcome his shortcomings [13].

questions.question: The PSR strictly prohibits an officer from undertaking any private agency in any matter connected with:
options: The exercise of his public duties
questions.explanation: No Officer shall undertake any private agency in any matter connected with the exercise of his public duties [14].

questions.question: Who must approve the release of any Officer on study leave, whether paid or unpaid, upon the recommendation of the Officer’s Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra Ministerial Office?
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: The release of any Officer on study leave shall be subject to the approval of the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation on the recommendation of the Officer’s Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra Ministerial Office [15].

questions.question: Who is responsible for maintaining and forwarding staff records, including the approved Staff Records Form, to the Pension Fund Administrator/National Pension Commission?
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: The Director (HRM) is responsible for ensuring staff records are completed and submitted to the Pension Fund Administrator/National Pension Commission [8].

questions.question: An officer on an incremental grade level shall normally be granted an increment unless he is on interdiction/suspension or:
options: Has completed the compulsory COMPRO exam
questions.explanation: An increment is withheld or deferred if the officer is on interdiction/suspension or has a disciplinary action pending [16].

questions.question: The deferment period for an officer's increment must be fixed and must not be less than three months nor more than:
questions.explanation: The deferment period must not be less than three months nor more than six months [17, 18].

questions.question: Which officer holds the authority to decide on restoring a deferred increment, requiring assessment of service improvement and conduct?
questions.explanation: The Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office holds the authority to decide on restoring a deferred increment [19].

subcategories.name: Circulars: Leave, Welfare & Allowances
subcategories.description: Official circular updates on leave, welfare, and allowances.

questions.question: Which Establishment Circular formally approved **Paternity Leave** for male officers in the Nigerian Public Service?
options: 2014 Circular on Leave Computation and Paternity Leave
questions.explanation: The 2014 OHCSF Circular on 'Computation of Leave Based on Working Days and Approval of Paternity Leave' formally introduced paternity leave for male officers [20].

questions.question: Under the 2014 Circular, computation of annual leave days is based on which calendar basis?
options: Working days, excluding weekends and public holidays
questions.explanation: Leave computation was adjusted to working days, excluding weekends and public holidays, for fairness and clarity [21, 22].

questions.question: The 2015 Establishment Circular directed that all MDAs must approve and submit their annual leave rosters by which quarter of the year?
questions.explanation: All MDAs were directed to submit approved leave rosters by the first quarter to enable effective planning and control of staff absences [23].

questions.question: The 2011 Circular on staff welfare mandated the establishment of which committee in MDAs to oversee staff wellbeing?
questions.explanation: The 2011 Circular mandated the creation of Welfare Committees to oversee staff wellbeing and morale within MDAs [24].

questions.question: The 2013 Circular on Staff Loans directed that loan applications must be supported by what document for verification?
questions.explanation: The Circular required that staff loan applications be accompanied by the applicant's most recent pay slip for verification [25].

questions.question: The 2012 Circular on Duty Tour Allowance (DTA) revised rates primarily based on what determining factor?
questions.explanation: The revised duty tour allowance rates were based on officers' grade levels to ensure equity and reflect inflation trends [26].

questions.question: Which specific body in the Federal Public Service reviews allowances and makes recommendations based on circulars initiated by the OHCSF?
options: The National Salaries, Incomes and Wages Commission (NSIWC)
The Budget Office of the Federation
questions.explanation: The National Salaries, Incomes and Wages Commission (NSIWC) reviews allowances in the Federal Public Service [27, 28].

questions.question: The maximum sick leave period before a Medical Board examination is mandatory, according to the PSR:
questions.explanation: If an officer is still not fit for duty after three months (90 days) sick leave, examination by a Medical Board shall be required [29, 30].

questions.question: Which category of leave practice is explicitly listed in the PSR (and consequently eliminated in operational circulars) as abolished?
questions.explanation: Deferred Leave is listed as one of the types of leave that is abolished [31].

questions.question: If an officer receives more leave during the leave year than they are eligible for, they will be required to refund the excess salary based on the number of:
options: Working days’ leave enjoyed in excess
questions.explanation: The officer shall be required to refund salary calculated at the rate it was paid for the number of working days’ leave enjoyed in excess [32].

questions.question: Officers who are going on religious pilgrimages, other than Officials assigned to cover such activities, should utilize which leave type?
questions.explanation: Officers going on religious pilgrimages should use part of their annual leave for such purposes [29].

questions.question: An officer who is dismissed from the service shall forfeit all claims to retiring benefits, leave, or transport grant, subject to the provisions of the:
questions.explanation: Dismissal results in forfeiture of benefits, subject to the provisions of the Pension Reform Act, 2014 (as amended) [33].

questions.question: The PSR mandates that all allowances, such as House Master/Mistress allowance or Science Teaching Allowance, shall be paid at the rates specified in which official document?
questions.explanation: Allowances are paid at the rates specified in the Extant Circular [17, 34, 35].

questions.question: What is the maximum duration of study leave with pay that may be granted to an Officer?
questions.explanation: The duration of study leave with pay shall not exceed two years [36, 37].

questions.question: The length of vacation leave granted to an Officer on invalidation (medically unfit to continue service) shall be two months and will commence:
options: Six months before the official retirement date
On the day the Medical Board declares him unfit
On the first day of the following calendar year
questions.explanation: The two months leave granted upon invalidation commences on the day the Medical Board declares the Officer permanently unfit for service [38].

questions.question: If an officer on vacation leave is recalled to duty by the Permanent Secretary, the officer is entitled to resume the unexpired portion of his leave when?
options: Immediately upon return to the office
On the day he ceases to hold a substantive post or act in another post in the same station
After three months of continuous service
Only at the discretion of the FCSC
questions.explanation: The unexpired portion of his leave may be resumed on the day he ceases to hold a substantive post, or act in another post in the same station [39].

subcategories.name: Circulars: Personnel, Performance & Reforms
subcategories.description: Official circular updates on personnel and reform directives.

questions.question: According to the 2015 Establishment Circular and PSR Rule 040102, which platform was mandated for salary and personnel management across all MDAs?
questions.explanation: The 2015 OHCSF Circular made the Integrated Personnel and Payroll Information System (IPPIS) mandatory for all MDAs to ensure payroll integrity [2].

questions.question: All newly employed Officers must be placed on the IPPIS platform within a maximum period of:
options: Two months of assumption of duty
questions.explanation: All Officers shall be placed on the IPPIS platform within two months of assumption of duty (Rule 040102) [40].

questions.question: The 2016 Circular on Biometric Capture mandated which activity for all public officers?
options: Completion of biometric registration for identity verification
questions.explanation: The 2016 OHCSF Circular on biometric integration mandated all public officers to complete biometric registration to ensure identity verification [41].

questions.question: The 2016 Circular on Performance Management introduced which modern HR evaluation tool to replace the Annual Performance Evaluation Report (APER)?
questions.explanation: The 2016 OHCSF Circular launched the Performance Management System (PMS) to replace the APER and align staff goals with organizational objectives [42].

questions.question: The Performance Management Cycle shall run from January to December of every year and shall commence immediately after the leadership of each MDA has finalized their:
options: Annual institutional and departmental goals and targets
questions.explanation: The PMS cycle commences immediately after the leadership of each MDA has finalized their annual institutional and departmental goals and targets [43].

questions.question: Which Establishment Circular reinforced **SERVICOM principles** to promote efficiency and citizen-focused service?
questions.explanation: The 2011 Circular on Service Delivery reinforced SERVICOM principles to promote efficiency and citizen-focused service [5].

questions.question: Who is primarily responsible for cascading the Performance Management System (PMS) framework throughout their respective MDAs for full implementation?
options: The Head of the Civil Service
questions.explanation: Permanent Secretaries were tasked with cascading the PMS framework throughout their MDAs for full implementation [43].

questions.question: The PSR incorporated provisions for **virtual meetings** primarily to reflect what modern necessity?
options: Enable remote work continuity during pandemics/emergencies
questions.explanation: Virtual meetings were introduced to enable remote work continuity during pandemics/emergencies, supporting uninterrupted government business [44].

questions.question: Who issues Treasury Circulars that provide detailed instructions on financial procedures and implementation, complementing the PSR and FR?
questions.explanation: The Accountant-General of the Federation issues Treasury Circulars [45].

questions.question: The purpose of the three months **pre-retirement leave** required of officers who give notice of retirement is primarily for:
options: To allow them to apply for transfer
To attend workshops and prepare documentation for retirement benefits
questions.explanation: The officer attends workshops and prepares documentation during the three months pre-retirement leave [46].

questions.question: The implementation of the Reward and Recognition Scheme (R&RS) is intended to encourage excellence, merit, and to ensure high levels of staff:
questions.explanation: The implementation of the R&RS System encourages excellence, merit, and ensures high levels of staff motivation [47].

questions.question: The Public Service Awards Ceremony, mandated under the R&RS, shall be held how often to recognize service-wide awardees?
questions.explanation: The Public Service Awards Ceremony shall be held annually [48].

questions.question: The policy governing training and capacity development strategies in the Federal Public Service is encapsulated in the:
options: Public Service Training and Capacity Development Policy
questions.explanation: Strategies for training are encapsulated in the Public Service Training and Capacity Development Policy [49].

questions.question: Who is statutorily designated as the Chief Financial Adviser to the Federal Government, coordinating fiscal circulars and policy?
questions.explanation: The Minister of Finance is the Chief Financial Adviser to the Federal Government [50].

questions.question: The compulsory Confirmation/Promotion Examination (COMPRO) must be passed by eligible officers within how many years from the date of taking up their appointments?
questions.explanation: Officers must pass the confirmation examination within two years from the date of taking up their appointments [11].

questions.question: When an Officer is seconded to another Ministry/Extra-Ministerial Office, who is responsible for providing the required performance reports on the Officer?
options: The Permanent Secretary of the releasing MDA
The Permanent Secretary/Head of the Extra-Ministerial Office to which he is seconded
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: The receiving MDA (host organization) is responsible for furnishing the performance reports [51, 52].

questions.question: If an officer on GL 14 meets all criteria, the minimum number of years required on the grade level before being considered for promotion to GL 15 is:
questions.explanation: An officer on GL 14 can be considered for promotion after spending a minimum of 3 years on the grade (Rule 020802(c)).
